questions.text: The middle radioulnar joint is an example of a: (INICET Nov 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Fibrous joint

 

Explanation:

 

The middle radioulnar joint is an example of a fibrous joint (syndesmosis).

 

Fibrous joints are joints where bones are connected by fibrous tissue, such as ligaments or sutures.

 

Examples of fibrous joints include the sutures of the skull and the syndesmosis between the radius and ulna at the distal radioulnar joint.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Plane synovial: Plane synovial joints are also known as gliding joints. They allow for limited gliding or sliding movements between flat articular surfaces. Examples of plane synovial joints include the intercarpal joints of the wrist.

 

Option B. Primary cartilaginous: Primary cartilaginous joints, also called synchondroses, are joints where bones are connected by hyaline cartilage. An example of a primary cartilaginous joint is the epiphyseal plate in growing long bones.

 

Option C. Secondary cartilaginous: Secondary cartilaginous joints, or symphyses, are joints where bones are connected by fibrocartilage. Examples include the intervertebral discs and the pubic symphysis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Three joints connect the radius and ulna to one another:

 

  • Proximal (superior) radioulnar joint
  • Middle radioulnar joint
  • Distal (inferior) radioulnar joint

 

Proximal and distal radioulnar joints are uniaxial pivot joints (synovial) and are involved in pronation and supination movements of the forearm.

 

The middle radioulnar joint is a fibrous joint (syndesmosis). The radius and ulna, in the middle, are connected by two syndesmoses namely:

 

  1. The oblique cord - extends distally from the radial tuberosity to the radius from the lateral side of the ulnar tuberosity.
  2. Interosseous membrane - a broad, thin collagenous structure, which runs perpendicular to the oblique cord. It extends distomedially between the interosseous borders of the radius and ulna.

choices.text: Carcinoid tumor
Gastrointestinal stromal tumor

questions.text: Which of the following is an epithelial tumor of the stomach? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Gastric adenocarcinoma

 

Gastric adenocarcinoma is an epithelial tumor of the stomach.

 

Adenocarcinoma is the most common malignancy (90% cases) of the stomach.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Carcinoid tumor: This is a neuroendocrine tumor.

 

Option B. Lymphoma: Represents a type of blood cancer originating from lymphocytes.

 

Option C. Gastrointestinal stromal tumor: A non-epithelial tumor that arises from the interstitial cells of Cajal in the gastrointestinal tract.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: Defect of enzyme tyrosine transaminase(FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Type 2 tyrosinemia

 

Explanation

 

Tyrosinemia is a genetic disorder characterized by the body's inability to effectively break down the amino acid tyrosine. There are three types of tyrosinemia, each associated with a specific enzyme deficiency:

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Type I tyrosinemia: This type is associated with a deficiency in fumarylacetoacetate hydrolase (FAH), not tyrosine transaminase.

 

Option C. Alkaptonuria: This condition involves a deficiency in the enzyme homogentisate 1,2-dioxygenase, not tyrosine transaminase.

 

Option D. Type III tyrosinemia: This type involves a deficiency in 4-hydroxyphenylpyruvate dioxygenase (HPPD), not tyrosine transaminase.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Type 2 tyrosinemia is caused by a deficiency in the enzyme tyrosine transaminase and is also known as Richner-Hanhart syndrome or Oculocutaneous syndrome.

questions.text: Conjunctival xerosis is associated with which vitamin deficiency? (FMGE JAN 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Vitamin A

 

Conjunctival xerosis, which refers to the drying and thickening of the conjunctiva, is indeed associated with Vitamin A deficiency. Vitamin A is crucial for maintaining the health of epithelial tissues, including those of the eye. This deficiency can lead to various ocular manifestations, including night blindness and xerophthalmia, of which conjunctival xerosis is a part.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Vitamin D: Vitamin D deficiency is primarily associated with conditions related to bone health, such as rickets in children and osteomalacia in adults. Conjunctival xerosis is not a recognized consequence of Vitamin D deficiency.

 

Option B. Vitamin K: Vitamin K deficiency is primarily associated with bleeding disorders due to impaired blood clotting. While Vitamin K deficiency can lead to bleeding in various tissues, conjunctival xerosis is not a recognized consequence of this deficiency.

 

Option C. Vitamin C: Vitamin C deficiency can lead to scurvy, which is characterized by symptoms such as bleeding gums, easy bruising, and impaired wound healing. However, conjunctival xerosis is not a typical manifestation of Vitamin C deficiency.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Conjunctival xerosis is specifically associated with Vitamin A deficiency and is a significant indicator of this deficiency, affecting the epithelial tissues of the eye.

questions.text: A 2-month pregnant female presented with Plasmodium vivax malaria. Which of the following is the appropriate treatment for this patient? (Fmge Jan 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Quinine

 

For a pregnant woman with Plasmodium vivax malaria, Chloroquine alone is the appropriate choice. Primaquine is contraindicated during pregnancy due to potential risks to the fetus. Quinine is normally used for Plasmodium falciparum malaria but can be used in P. vivax malaria also if other options are not available. It is safe in pregnancy. ACTs are generally avoided in the first trimester, and Doxycycline is contraindicated in pregnancy. Therefore, Chloroquine, without Primaquine, is the safest and most effective option in this case. However, as it is not in the options, so the next best option i.e. quinine will be the answer.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Chloroquine plus Primaquine: Chloroquine is considered safe and effective for the treatment of Plasmodium vivax malaria during pregnancy. However, primaquine is contraindicated in pregnancy due to the risk of hemolytic anemia in the fetus, especially if there is G6PD deficiency, which cannot be tested for in the fetus.

 

Option C. Artemisinin-Based Combination Therapy (ACT): While ACTs are very effective in treating Plasmodium falciparum malaria, their safety profile in the first trimester of pregnancy is not well-established. Generally, they are avoided in the first trimester unless no other options are available.

 

Option D. Doxycycline: Doxycycline is contraindicated in pregnancy due to the risk of interfering with bone and teeth development in the fetus.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Quinine is often used as a treatment for malaria during pregnancy, especially if other options are not available or suitable. However, it is usually more associated with the treatment of Plasmodium falciparum rather than Plasmodium vivax.

questions.text: Which of the following amino acid is necessary for conversion of nor-epinephrine to epinephrine? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Methionine

 

Methionine is involved in the conversion of norepinephrine to epinephrine. It donate methyl group in the form of SAM.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Tyrosine: It is the precursor amino acid for the synthesis of both norepinephrine and epinephrine in the catecholamine biosynthetic pathway. But it is not directly involved in their intercomversion,

 

Option B. Tryptophan: Tryptophan is not directly involved in the synthesis of norepinephrine or epinephrine. Tryptophan is an essential amino acid and serves as the precursor for serotonin, melatonin, and niacin (vitamin B3).

 

Option C. Phenylalanine: Phenylalanine is not directly involved in the synthesis of norepinephrine or epinephrine. It is an essential amino acid and serves as the precursor for tyrosine through the action of the enzyme phenylalanine hydroxylase.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Methionine is necessary for the conversion of nor-epinephrine to epinephrine.

 

Norepinephrine is methylated by the enzyme N-methyl transferase (NMT) to epinephrine or adrenaline.

 

S-adenosyl methionine (SAM) is the methyl donor. It is mainly produced by adrenal medulla and adrenergic nerve endings. It is stored in chromaffin granules and released into blood.

questions.text: A patient presents with symptoms of tachycardia, tachypnea, hypertension, and hypocalcemia after consuming an unknown substance. There was presence of high anion gap metabolic acidosis. Which of the following substances was most likely consumed? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Ethylene glycol

 

Ethylene glycol poisoning is characterized by the presence of high anion gap metabolic acidosis (HAGMA) and hypocalcemia, which are key features mentioned in the case.

 

Ethylene glycol is metabolized in the body to glycolic acid and subsequently to oxalic acid. Oxalic acid binds with calcium to form calcium oxalate crystals, which can precipitate in various tissues, leading to hypocalcemia. The metabolic acidosis arises due to the accumulation of glycolic acid and oxalic acid. Additionally, ethylene glycol poisoning presents with symptoms similar to alcohol intoxication, including tachycardia, tachypnea, and hypertension, all of which are described in the patient.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Iron: Iron poisoning typically causes metabolic acidosis but does not lead to hypocalcemia or the specific combination of symptoms described here. Instead, iron toxicity more commonly causes gastrointestinal symptoms and systemic toxicity.

 

Option B. Methanol: Methanol poisoning can also cause high anion gap metabolic acidosis, but it is more associated with visual disturbances and CNS depression rather than hypocalcemia and the specific symptom profile of ethylene glycol poisoning.

 

Option D. Digoxin: Digoxin toxicity can cause a variety of symptoms including arrhythmias, but it does not typically cause metabolic acidosis or hypocalcemia. Its toxicity is primarily related to cardiac symptoms rather than the systemic effects described here.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Ethylene glycol poisoning should be suspected in patients presenting with high anion gap metabolic acidosis, hypocalcemia, and symptoms resembling alcohol intoxication. The formation of oxalate crystals and the subsequent hypocalcemia are key features that differentiate it from other toxic ingestions.

questions.text: What is the likely diagnosis of a child with cleft lip and palate with microphthalmia and umbilical hernia? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Patau syndrome

 

The clinical features described in the question—cleft lip and palate, microphthalmia (small eyes), and umbilical hernia—are characteristic of Patau syndrome (Trisomy 13). Patau syndrome is a genetic disorder caused by the presence of an extra copy of chromosome 13.

 

Children with Patau syndrome often present with multiple congenital anomalies, including:

 

  • Cleft lip and palate
  • Microphthalmia (small, underdeveloped eyes)
  • Umbilical hernia
  • Polydactyly (extra fingers or toes)
  • Congenital heart defects
  • Rocker-bottom feet

 

These features, especially when occurring together, strongly suggest a diagnosis of Patau syndrome.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Edward syndrome: Also known as Trisomy 18, it is characterized by features like micrognathia (small jaw), prominent occiput, overlapping fingers, and rocker-bottom feet. While some features overlap with Patau syndrome, the presence of cleft lip and palate along with microphthalmia and umbilical hernia points more towards Patau syndrome.

 

Option C. Turner syndrome: Turner syndrome affects females and is caused by the complete or partial absence of one X chromosome. It is associated with features such as short stature, webbed neck, and gonadal dysgenesis, but not with cleft lip, palate, or microphthalmia.

 

Option D. Prader-Willi syndrome: This syndrome is characterized by hypotonia, poor feeding in infancy, obesity, intellectual disability, and hypogonadism, but not by cleft lip and palate or microphthalmia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Patau syndrome (Trisomy 13) presents with multiple congenital anomalies, including cleft lip and palate, microphthalmia, and umbilical hernia, making it the most likely diagnosis in this case.

questions.text: A patient underwent endoscopy, during the procedure perforation occurred at 25 cm from the incisors. Which structure is likely to be damaged? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Arch of aorta

 

During an endoscopy, if a perforation occurs at 25 cm from the incisors, the structure most likely to be damaged is the arch of the aorta. At this anatomical level, the esophagus is in close proximity to the arch of the aorta and the left bronchus. The esophagus traverses behind the arch of the aorta around this distance from the upper incisors, making it susceptible to injury in the event of a perforation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Diaphragm: The diaphragm is located approximately 40 cm from the incisors, much lower than the site of perforation.

 

Option C. Pharyngoesophageal junction: This junction is situated around 15 cm from the incisors, which is too high up the esophagus to be relevant to a perforation at 25 cm.

 

Option D. Right bronchus: The right bronchus is not in proximity to the esophagus at the 25 cm mark. It is the left bronchus that is close to the esophagus at this level, but it was not listed as an option.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Perforation at 25 cm from the incisors during endoscopy is most likely to involve the arch of the aorta due to its anatomical position relative to the esophagus.

questions.text: The anterior incisors of a child with white patches turned brown following over supplementation of: (FMGE JANUARY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Fluorine in water

 

Explanation:

 

The description of white patches turning brown on the anterior incisors of a child is indicative of dental fluorosis. This condition occurs due to excessive fluoride intake, particularly during the years when teeth are developing. Fluoride is beneficial in small amounts for dental health, but excessive exposure, often due to high levels in drinking water or overuse of fluoride supplements, can lead to fluorosis, which manifests as mottling and discoloration of teeth.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Chlorine in Water: While chlorine is used to purify water, it does not cause dental fluorosis, which is characterized by changes in the color and structure of teeth. Chlorine at levels used in water treatment does not typically result in dental discoloration.

 

Option C. Vitamin A: While excessive Vitamin A intake can lead to toxicity with a variety of symptoms, it does not cause dental fluorosis. Vitamin A toxicity typically presents with symptoms such as skin changes, vision disturbances, and bone pain, but not with changes in tooth color.

 

Option D. Riboflavin: Riboflavin (Vitamin B2) is not associated with dental discoloration. Deficiency of riboflavin can lead to mouth and lip sores, but its excess does not result in changes similar to fluorosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Fluoride prevents caries, as topical application of fluoride will result in a fluorapatite layer on the enamel, which protects enamel from the decay by acid.
  • The safe limit of fluorine is about 1 ppm in water.
  • Fluoride level >>2 ppm causes chronic intestinal upset, gastroenteritis, loss of appetite and loss of weight.
  • Level >>5 ppm causes mottling of enamel, stratification and discoloration of teeth.
  • A level >>>20 ppm is toxic and causes alternate areas of osteoporosis and osteosclerosis with brittle bones known as fluorosis.

 

Ref: Textbook of Medical biochemistry 3rd edition Page no. 416

questions.text: During which phase of cardiac cycle is the first heart sound produced? (FMGE JANUARY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Isovolumetric contraction

 

Isovolumetric contraction is the phase during which the first heart sound (S1) is produced. This sound is primarily due to the closure of the mitral and tricuspid valves at the start of ventricular contraction, which prevents the backflow of blood into the atria and generates a sound marking the beginning of systole.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Rapid ejection phase: Incorrect because this phase follows the isovolumetric contraction and involves the ejection of blood into the aorta and pulmonary trunk as the ventricles contract further and the pressure exceeds that of the arteries. The valves are already open, and no significant sound is produced akin to S1 during this phase.

 

Option C. Slow ejection phase: Incorrect as this phase represents the tail end of the ejection process where the remaining blood is pushed out of the ventricles at a slower rate due to decreasing pressure gradients. Like the rapid ejection phase, it does not involve the opening or closing of valves that would produce a distinct heart sound.

 

Option D. Isovolumetric relaxation: Incorrect because this phase involves the relaxation of the ventricles without any change in volume, marked by the closure of the aortic and pulmonary valves, which produces the second heart sound (S2), not the first

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Phases of cardiac cycle -

 

  • Cardiac cycle in ventricles last for 0.8 sec
  • Ventricular Systole - 0.3 sec.  – consist of 3 phases.
  • Ventricular Diastole - 0,5 sec - consist of 5 phases.

 

Phases of ventricular Systole -

 

1st Phase - Starts with closure of Mitral valve, which produces S1 sound. This phase is called as Isovolumetric contraction, it ends by opening of aortic valve.

 

2nd Phase - Phase of Rapid ejection - 2/3rd of the stroke volume is ejected.

 

3rd Phase - Phase of Slow ejection phase: Approximately 1/3rd of the remaining stroke volume is ejected

 

Phases of ventricular Diastole -

 

1st phase (Protodiastole) – which occurs just before the beginning of diastole (last for 0.04 Sec.)

 

2nd Phase - starts with closure of aortic valve, which produces S2 sound which is taken as- beginning of diastole proper. This phase is known as Isovolumetric relaxation.

 

Volume - constant, pressure – decrease

 

3rd Phase - Early Rapid filling phase and 4th Slow filling phase (passive filling of 2/3rd of blood)

 

* S3 sound produce due to rapid filling phase. Normally Can not be heard except few Hyperdynamic condition like: exercise, Pregnancy

 

4. Active filling phase (Remaining 1/3rd of filling due to atrial contraction)

choices.text: Immunosuppression can be continued during pregnancy
Pregnancy to be planned once the disease has been quiescent for at least 6 months and there is no evidence of renal dysfunction
High dose corticosteroids for lupus flare in pregnancy is safe
Ecospirin, methotrexate, cyclophosphamide, corticosteroids, azathioprine are safe in pregnancy

questions.text: Which of the following is not true about lupus nephritis in pregnancy? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Ecospirin, methotrexate, cyclophosphamide, corticosteroids, azathioprine are safe in pregnancy

 

Explanation:

 

  • SLE is a chronic autoimmune disorder involving the multisystem. It affects young women of childbearing age. The renal involvement of the disease can manifest in the form of active lupus nephritis or flare-ups during pregnancy.
  • It can lead to preterm births, preeclampsia, and pregnancy loss while the infant can suffer from neonatal lupus and heart block.
  • Management includes
  • Preconceptionally counseling: Conception during a period of quiescence for at least 6 months determines a successful outcome. Stable remission of renal disease for at least 6 months before conception is recommended.
  • Corticosteroids are useful during episodes of lupus flare and can be used safely in pregnancy.
  • Immunosuppressants such as azathioprine can be continued during pregnancy. It may be used in case of severe SLE
  • Hydroxychloroquine is found to be the best for maintenance and is safe in pregnancy. It can prevent the need for prolonged corticosteroid therapy.
  • Methotrexate and cyclophosphamide are teratogenic and hence they are not safe during pregnancy.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Immunosuppression can be continued during pregnancy: Correct. Medications like azathioprine can be continued under medical guidance, while others are used cautiously.

 

Option B. Pregnancy to be planned once the disease has been quiescent for at least 6 months and there is no evidence of renal dysfunction: Correct. Quiescence of the disease and stable renal function are crucial for a successful pregnancy outcome.

 

Option C. High dose corticosteroids for lupus flare in pregnancy is safe: Correct. High doses of corticosteroids can be used during a lupus flare, but must be carefully monitored.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Methotrexate and cyclophosphamide are not safe during pregnancy for managing lupus nephritis; corticosteroids and azathioprine are safer options.

 

Ref: Page 2895, Williams Obstetrics 26th edition

questions.text: What is the most common cause of moderate-severe visual impairment according to the National Blindness and Visual Impairment Survey 2015-19?(INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Untreated cataract

 

The National Blindness and Visual Impairment Survey conducted from 2015 to 2019 revealed that untreated cataract is the leading cause of moderate-severe visual impairment (MSVI). MSVI is characterized by a presenting visual acuity of <6/18 to 3/60 in the better eye despite available correction. Visual impairment and blindness are frequently observed in individuals who are 50 years old and above.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A: Refractive errors are the leading cause of MSVI in patients aged 49 years and below.

 

Options C and Option D: Glaucoma and diabetic retinopathy account for a very low number of visual impairment cases in patients aged 50 years and above.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The prevalence of untreated cataracts as a leading cause of moderate-severe visual impairment emphasizes the need for effective public health strategies focusing on eye health screenings and accessible cataract surgery to reduce the burden of preventable blindness and visual impairment.

questions.text: Which of the following diuretic is correctly matched with its site of action (INICET May 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Carbonic anhydrase inhibitors - Proximal tubule

 

Carbonic anhydrase inhibitors - These act in the proximal tubule. Acetazolamide is a commonly used carbonic anhydrase inhibitor.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Osmotic diuretics- Collecting duct: These work primarily in the proximal tubule and the descending limb of the loop of Henle, not the collecting duct. Mannitol is a common example.

 

Option C. Thiazides-Loop of Henle: These primarily act on the distal convoluted tubule. Hydrochlorothiazide is a typical example.

 

Option D. Aldosterone antagonists- early Distal tubules: These work in the collecting ducts and late distal tubules. Spironolactone is a well-known aldosterone antagonist.

questions.text: A patient is brought to the hospital, with complaints of seizures and the MRI image of the brain is given below. The disease is most probably caused by? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Cysticercosis cellulose

 

The given clinical scenario and MRI brain showing scolex within multiple cystic lesions are suggestive of neurocysticercosis caused by the larval form of T. solium called Cysticercosis cellulose.

 

Neurocysticercosis is the most common central nervous system parasitic infection.

 

The clinical features of neurocysticercosis include:

 

  • ﻿﻿Epilepsy
  • ﻿﻿Increased intracranial tension
  • ﻿﻿Hydrocephalus
  • ﻿﻿Psychiatric disturbances
  • ﻿﻿Meningoencephalitis
  • ﻿﻿Transient paresis
  • ﻿﻿Behavioral disorders
  • ﻿﻿Aphasia
  • ﻿﻿Visual disturbances.

 

The CT and MRI findings seen in neurocysticercosis are:

 

  • ﻿﻿Scolex within a cyst
  • ﻿﻿Cystic lesions with or without ring enhancement
  • ﻿﻿Nodular calcifications
  • ﻿﻿Focal enhancing lesions
  • ﻿﻿Multilobulated cystic lesions in the subarachnoid space.

 

Note: About 70% of adult-onset epilepsy is due to neurocysticercosis.

 

Albendazole is the drug of choice for neurocysticercosis. Glucocorticoid therapy is usually begun before initiating albendazole (antiparasitic drug). This is continued for several days after the institution of therapy to reduce the incidence of side effects from inflammatory reactions to dead and dying cysticerci of Taenia solium.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. T. saginata: Incorrect. Known as the beef tapeworm, it does not typically lead to cysticercosis as its larvae (Cysticercus bovis) primarily infect cattle.

 

Option C. Cysticercosis bovis: Incorrect. This term is not applicable to human disease and refers to the larval stage of T. saginata found in cattle.

 

Option D. T. asiatica: Incorrect. This is a species of tapeworm similar to T. saginata and is associated with pigs, but like T. saginata, it is not commonly linked to neurocysticercosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Neurocysticercosis is identified with imaging studies, particularly in patients presenting with new-onset seizures and specific MRI findings of cystic lesions with scolex, is critical for timely diagnosis and appropriate management, including antiparasitic and supportive therapy.

questions.text: Which of the following anti-diabetic drug is associated with increased risk of urinary tract infections? (INICET May 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Dapagliflozin

 

Dapagliflozin is a sodium-glucose cotransporter-2 (SGLT2) inhibitor. SGLT2 inhibitors work by promoting the excretion of glucose through the urine. This increased urinary glucose can create an environment that promotes the growth of bacteria, thereby increasing the risk of urinary tract infections. This class of drugs is well known for its association with UTIs and genital infections.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Pioglitazone: Pioglitazone is a thiazolidinedione that improves insulin sensitivity. It is not associated with an increased risk of urinary tract infections. Common side effects include weight gain, edema, and an increased risk of heart failure.

 

Option C. Sitagliptin: Sitagliptin is a dipeptidyl peptidase-4 (DPP-4) inhibitor. It works by increasing incretin levels, which in turn increase insulin secretion and decrease glucagon secretion. Sitagliptin is not commonly associated with an increased risk of urinary tract infections.

 

Option D. Metformin: Metformin is a biguanide that decreases hepatic glucose production and improves insulin sensitivity. It is not associated with an increased risk of urinary tract infections. Common side effects of metformin include gastrointestinal disturbances such as diarrhea and abdominal discomfort.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In summary, dapagliflozin, an SGLT2 inhibitor, is associated with an increased risk of urinary tract infections due to its mechanism of increasing glucose excretion in the urine. This patient’s recurrent UTIs could be related to her use of dapagliflozin.

questions.text: Which type of intracranial hemorrhage is most likely depicted in the given image? (FMGE JAN 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Subdural hematoma 

 

The image provided shows a computed tomography (CT) scan of the brain with a collection of blood within the skull but outside the brain tissue. 

 

This type of hemorrhage occurs beneath the dura mater and above the arachnoid layer. It commonly appears as a crescent-shaped collection that can cross suture lines but is limited by dural attachments such as the falx and tentorium.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Extradural hemorrhage (also known as epidural hematoma): Typically biconvex in shape and does not cross suture lines due to the firm attachment of the dura to the skull at the sutures. It is often associated with a skull fracture and middle meningeal artery rupture.

 

Option B. Subarachnoid hemorrhage: Blood is located under the arachnoid membrane, in the subarachnoid space, where cerebrospinal fluid circulates. On a CT scan, it appears as areas of increased density in the sulci and cisterns, rather than a localized collection.

 

Option D. Intraparenchymal hemorrhage: This is bleeding directly into the brain tissue and appears as a localized area of increased density within the brain parenchyma itself.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

The crescent-shaped collection of blood on a CT scan that can cross suture lines but is limited by dural reflections is indicative of a subdural hematoma, a type of intracranial hemorrhage that occurs between the dura mater and the arachnoid layer.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male, presents to the emergency department with complaints of severe pain, swelling and redness in scrotal area. He undergoes a surgical procedure for the same. Based on the image below, what is the likely diagnosis?(NEET  PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Fournier’s gangrene

 

  • The given postoperative image is suggestive of the "shameful exposure of testes" done after debridement for Fournier’s gangrene.
  • Fournier's gangrene is a rare but serious bacterial infection of the scrotum and perineum area leading to gangrene.
  • It is characterized by rapid and progressive necrosis (death) of the tissue in the genital and perineal regions and can spread to the surrounding tissue and organs.
  • Symptoms of Fournier's gangrene may include severe pain, swelling, redness, and foul-smelling discharge from the affected area.
  • Early diagnosis and treatment with antibiotics and surgical debridement (removal of dead tissue) are critical in managing Fournier's gangrene, as the condition can be life-threatening if left untreated.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Torsion of testis: Testicular torsion is a medical emergency that occurs when the spermatic cord, which provides blood flow to the testicle, rotates and becomes twisted. This cuts off the blood flow and can lead to the death of the testicle if not treated promptly. Symptoms typically include sudden and severe pain in one testicle, swelling, redness, and often nausea and vomiting. The affected testicle may lie horizontally and be high-riding. Testicular torsion requires immediate surgical intervention to untwist the spermatic cord and save the testicle.

 

Option B. Acute epididymo-orchitis: Epididymo-orchitis is the inflammation of the epididymis and/or testicle. It is usually caused by an infection, which can be either bacterial or viral. Symptoms include pain, redness, and swelling in the scrotal area, often accompanied by fever. The affected area would be tender on palpation. Treatment typically involves antibiotics and pain relief.

 

Option C. Scrotal carcinoma: Scrotal carcinoma would present as a growth or ulcerative lesion on the skin of the scrotum. It wouldn't typically cause the acute, severe symptoms described in the scenario. However, it is essential to consider malignancy in long-standing, non-healing ulcers or growths in the scrotal area.

 

  • Given the severe pain, swelling, redness, and the nature of the postoperative image showing debridement, Fournier's gangrene (Option D) is the most likely diagnosis for this patient.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Fournier's gangrene is a life-threatening condition requiring urgent surgical intervention and aggressive antibiotic therapy.
  • Early recognition and prompt treatment are crucial to improve patient outcomes.

questions.text: A 28-year-old pregnant woman presents with a history of decreased fetal movements and respiratory distress in her newborn. On examination, the neonate appears cyanotic with increased work of breathing. Auscultation reveals bowel sounds in the left hemithorax. Chest x-ray showed multiple air fluid levels. Which of the following congenital anomalies is most likely responsible for these findings? (FMGE JAN 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Congenital diaphragmatic hernia 

 

  • The clinical picture of a cyanotic newborn with respiratory distress and auscultation revealing bowel sounds in the left hemithorax, combined with chest X-ray showing multiple air-fluid levels, is suggestive of a congenital anomaly that allows abdominal contents into the thoracic cavity. 
  • CDH is a defect in the diaphragm that allows abdominal organs to herniate into the thoracic cavity, impairing lung development and causing respiratory distress and cyanosis after birth. The presence of bowel sounds in the thorax and air-fluid levels on X-ray are indicative of this condition.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Tetralogy of Fallot: This is a congenital heart defect that includes four abnormalities: ventricular septal defect, pulmonary stenosis, right ventricular hypertrophy, and an overriding aorta. It leads to cyanotic congenital heart disease but does not cause bowel sounds in the thorax or air-fluid levels on X-ray.

 

Option C. Transposition of the great vessels: This is another congenital heart defect where the major vessels (the aorta and the pulmonary artery) are switched. It results in cyanosis but would not cause bowel sounds in the chest or air-fluid levels on X-ray.

 

Option D. Tracheoesophageal fistula: This condition involves an abnormal connection between the trachea and esophagus, which can lead to respiratory distress due to aspiration, but it would not cause bowel sounds in the thorax or the radiographic appearance of air-fluid levels as seen with CDH.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Congenital diaphragmatic hernia is most likely responsible for the clinical findings of cyanosis, respiratory distress, and bowel sounds in the chest of a newborn, along with air-fluid levels on chest X-ray.

questions.text: A female patient presents with nasal obstruction, nasal discharge, and loss of smell. On examination, foul-smelling discharge and yellowish-green crusts are present in the nasal cavity. She is found to have merciful anosmia. Which of the following finding can also be seen during the examination of her nose? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Roomy nasal cavity

 

ATROPHIC RHINITIS:

 

Pathology - Ciliated columnar epithelium is lost and is replaced by stratified squamous type. There is atrophy of seromucinous glands, venous blood sinusoids and nerve elements. Arteries in the mucosa, periosteum and bone show obliterative endarteritis. The bone of turbinates undergoes resorption causing widening of nasal chambers. Paranasal sinuses are small due to their arrested development.

 

Clinical Features

 

  1. Commonly seen in females and starts around puberty
  2. Foul smell from the nose though the patient himself is unaware of the smell due to marked anosmia (merciful anosmia) which accompanies these degenerative changes.
  3. Patients may complain of nasal obstruction due to large crusts filling the nose.
  4. Epistaxis may occur when the crusts are removed.

 

On examination shows

 

  1. Nasal cavity to be full of greenish or grayish black dry crusts covering the turbinates and septum. Attempts to remove them may cause bleeding.
  2. When the crusts have been removed, nasal cavities appear roomy with atrophy of turbinates.
  3. Nasal mucosa appears pale. Septal perforation and dermatitis of nasal vestibule may be present. Nose may show a saddle deformity.
  4.  Atrophic changes may also be seen in the pharyngeal mucosa larynx.
  5. Hearing impairment may be noticed because of obstruction to the eustachian tube and middle ear effusion.
  6. Paranasal sinuses are usually small and underdeveloped with thick walls.

 

Treatment:

 

  • Nasal irrigation - using warm saline or an alkaline solution composed of sodium bicarbonate 1 part, sodium biborate 1 part, sodium chloride 2 parts in 280 mL of water
  • Local antibiotics - Kemicetine antiozaena solution containing chloromycetin, estradiol, and vitamin D2.
  • 25% glucose in glycerine, estradiol spray, systemic use of streptomycin, potassium iodide, placental extract.

 

Surgical management:

 

  • Young's operation: In this procedure, flaps are raised within the nasal vestibule and both the nostrils are completely closed and are opened after 6 months. During this time, the mucosa may revert to normal and the crusting is reduced.
  • Modified young's operation: In this procedure, the nostrils are partially closed and thereby avoiding the discomfort from complete closure of the nostrils. The results are the same compared to Young's operation.
  • Narrowing of the nasal cavity can be done by submucosal injection of Teflon paste, or by insertion of fat, cartilage, or Teflon strips under the mucoperiosteum.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Nasal polyps: These are non-neoplastic masses of the edematous nasal or sinus mucosa. Nasal polyps can be antrochoanal polyps or ethmoidal polyps.

 

Option C. Inferior turbinate hypertrophy: It is associated with various mucosal diseases which include allergic rhinitis, infectious rhinitis, and vasomotor rhinitis. It can cause chronic nasal obstruction.

 

Option D. Foreign body nose: It is commonly seen in children and the child presents with unilateral, foul-smelling nasal discharge.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Atrophic rhinitis leads to significant structural changes within the nasal cavity, most notably an enlargement of the space due to bone and soft tissue atrophy. Recognizing these changes is crucial for diagnosing and managing the condition effectively, with treatments often focusing on moisturizing the nasal cavity and addressing the underlying atrophic changes.

 

Ref - Dhingra 7th edition, Page No. 172, 173

questions.text: Which of the following is correct regarding the X-Ray image shown? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Jejunal atresia

 

The X-ray image provided shows a characteristic feature known as the "triple bubble" appearance, which is indicative of jejunal atresia. In the context of pediatric radiology, this appearance is caused by the presence of three dilated gas-filled bowel loops proximal to the atretic segment of the jejunum. Jejunal atresia is a congenital condition where there is an obstruction in the jejunum, leading to this distinctive radiological sign.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Duodenal atresia: This condition typically presents with a "double bubble" sign on an X-ray, not a triple bubble. The double bubble sign shows two dilated areas—one in the stomach and one in the duodenum—due to an obstruction in the duodenum.

 

Option C. Pneumoperitoneum: This condition involves the presence of free air in the peritoneal cavity, usually due to gastrointestinal perforation. The X-ray sign is free air under the diaphragm, which is not seen in the given image.

 

Option D. Hirschsprung’s disease: This is a congenital condition characterized by the absence of ganglion cells in the distal colon, leading to obstruction. The radiographic features might include a distended colon with a transition zone, but it does not present with the triple bubble appearance.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Radiological findings:

 

  • Jejunal atresia or ileal atresia: Triple Bubble Appearance
  • Duodenal atresia: Double Bubble sign
  • Infantile pyloric stenosis: Single Bubble sign

choices.text: Basal stent placement

questions.text: Interventional technique used for the management of cerebral aneurysm: (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Coiling

 

The management of cerebral aneurysms, particularly berry aneurysms, involves two primary interventional techniques: clipping and coiling.

 

  • Coiling: This is an endovascular procedure where a catheter is inserted through the femoral artery and navigated to the aneurysm. Coils are then deployed into the aneurysm to induce thrombosis and prevent rupture. Coiling has lower morbidity and mortality rates compared to surgical clipping and is preferred if the aneurysm is accessible for endovascular treatment.
  • Clipping: This involves a craniotomy where the skull is opened, and a clip is placed at the neck of the aneurysm to isolate it from the circulation. While effective, it is more invasive compared to coiling.

 

Other options:

 

Option B. Embolization: While embolization is used in various vascular interventions, it is not the preferred technique for managing cerebral aneurysms.

 

Option C. Basal stent placement: Stents may be used as an adjunct to coiling to support the coil mass and ensure complete occlusion of the aneurysm, but stent placement alone is not effective for managing aneurysms.

 

Option D. Balloon Angioplasty: This technique is used to dilate narrowed blood vessels but is not suitable for treating aneurysms as it can worsen the aneurysm by increasing the risk of rupture.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The preferred interventional technique for the management of cerebral aneurysms is endovascular coiling due to its lower morbidity and mortality compared to surgical clipping.

questions.text: A patient present with symptoms of dermatitis, diarrhea, and cognitive decline. Which micronutrient deficiency is most likely responsible? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Niacin

 

The patient's symptoms—dermatitis, diarrhea, and cognitive decline (dementia)—represent the classic triad of pellagra, which is associated with niacin (vitamin B3) deficiency. Pellagra is commonly summarized as the "3 Ds": dermatitis, diarrhea, and dementia. In severe untreated cases, it can lead to a fourth "D," which is death. Niacin deficiency can occur due to poor dietary intake, malabsorption disorders, or conditions that affect tryptophan metabolism, such as Hartnup disease and carcinoid syndrome.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Thiamine: Thiamine (vitamin B1) deficiency leads to beriberi, which manifests as dry beriberi (peripheral neuropathy) or wet beriberi (cardiac failure). It can also cause Wernicke's encephalopathy and Korsakoff's psychosis, particularly in alcoholics, but it does not cause dermatitis or diarrhea.

 

Option C. Pyridoxine: Pyridoxine (vitamin B6) deficiency is associated with symptoms such as peripheral neuropathy, depression, and seizures. It does not typically cause the 3D symptoms seen in pellagra unless it indirectly leads to niacin deficiency by impairing tryptophan metabolism.

 

Option D. Retinol: Retinol (vitamin A) deficiency primarily affects vision, immune function, and skin health, causing conditions like night blindness and xerophthalmia, but it does not cause diarrhea or cognitive decline.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Pellagra, characterized by dermatitis, diarrhea, and dementia, is primarily caused by niacin deficiency.

questions.text: The last symptoms to develop in compartment syndrome is: (INICET MAY 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Pulselessness

 

COMPARTMENT SYNDROME

 

  • In acute compartment syndrome, increased pressure in a close fascial space causes loss of microcirculation.

  • Most commonly compartment syndrome involves deep posterior compartment of leg > deep flexor compartment of forearm (commonest in children).

  • It is most commonly seen following fractures of supracondylar humerus and tibia.

  • Clinical Features:

  • The diagnosis of compartment syndrome is based on dramatically increasing pain (out of proportion to injury) after fracture/any injury (1st symptom) not even getting relieved on analgesics.

  • Pain and resistance on passive stretch (Distal most joint of extremity) – 1st sign.

  • Pulselessness is a late feature and it is not a reliable indicator of compartment syndrome. The presence of pulse does not exclude the diagnosis. 

  • In later stages, paresthesia and paralysis ensue due to nerve involvement.

  • Acute compartment syndrome presents with the following 5 Ps:

 

 

  • Paralysis and Pulselessness are considered late and ominous signs, indicating severe and irreversible tissue damage. 
  • Paralysis and pulselessness signifies that the condition has progressed significantly, indicating permanent injury.
  • Pulselessness generally represents a more critical and terminal stage of circulatory compromise.
  • It implies complete or near-complete cessation of blood flow, which is ultimately the most severe and final physiological sign of impending tissue death.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pain on passive stretch. Pain and resistance to the passive stretch is the first sign of the compartment syndrome. 

 

Option B. Paralysis. Paralysis occurs in the late stages of the syndrome due to involvement of the nerves. 

 

Option C. Pallor. Pallor appears in the late stages and indicates irreversible muscle and nerve ischemia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The last sign/symptom to appear in a compartment syndrome is pulselessness, as it signifies the most advanced stage of vascular compromise. 

  • While paralysis is also very late, the absence of a pulse is a definitive sign of severe, critical ischemia.

questions.text: Mycoplasma is inherently resistant to which of the following antibiotics? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Beta lactam antibiotics

 

Mycoplasma is inherently resistant to beta-lactam antibiotics.

 

Mycoplasma lack cell wall, and therefore, are inherently resistant to beta-lactam antibiotics as these drugs act on the cell wall.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Macrolides: Incorrect, as macrolides are effective against Mycoplasma. They work by inhibiting protein synthesis and are commonly used to treat infections caused by these bacteria.

 

Option C. Tetracycline: Incorrect, tetracyclines are also effective against Mycoplasma and work by inhibiting bacterial protein synthesis.

 

Option D. Fluoroquinolones: Incorrect, fluoroquinolones, which inhibit bacterial DNA synthesis, are effective against a broad range of bacteria, including Mycoplasma.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The unique features of Mycoplasma is the absence of a cell wall, this is why beta-lactam antibiotics are not suitable for treating infections caused by Mycoplasma.

questions.text: Maximum brain growth occurs at which year of life? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 2 years

 

Brain growth reaches its maximum around 2 years of age. This early and rapid growth phase is crucial for the development of cognitive and motor skills, and it aligns with significant milestones in early childhood development, such as language acquisition, sensory processing, and coordination. The early years are critical for brain development, as synaptic connections are formed at a rapid pace during this time.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. 6 years: At 6 years of age, the lymphoid tissues reach their maximum size. The lymphoid system includes the tonsils, adenoids, and other components of the immune system, which are prominent in early childhood to protect against infections.

 

Option C. 10 years: This age is not specifically associated with peak growth in any of the major developmental domains mentioned (brain, lymphoid, somatic, or puberty).

 

Option D. 12 years: This age marks the peak growth for somatic (body) growth and the onset of puberty. During this period, there is a significant increase in height and secondary sexual characteristics as the body undergoes maturation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The maximum brain growth occurs by 2 years of age, emphasizing the importance of early childhood for brain development.

 

Remember:

 

  • Brain Growth max at 2 years
  • Lymphoid Growth max at 6 years
  • Puberty and Somatic Growth max at 12 years

questions.text: A 55-year-old female with a history of chronic stable angina is seen in the outpatient department. She is already taking aspirin and statins, but continues to experience occasional chest pain during exertion. Which of the following would be the most appropriate choice for prophylactic treatment of her angina? (Fmge July 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Oral nitroglycerine

 

Oral nitroglycerine is the most appropriate choice for the prophylactic treatment of chronic stable angina in this patient. Long-acting nitrate preparations, like oral nitroglycerine, are used to prevent angina episodes rather than for immediate relief.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Sublingual nitroglycerine: This is used for rapid relief during an acute angina attack, not as a prophylactic treatment.

 

Option B. Intravenous nitroglycerine: This form is typically used in acute care settings, such as for unstable angina or during a myocardial infarction, not for routine prophylaxis.

 

Option D. Intratracheal nitroglycerine: This is not a recognized route of administration for nitroglycerine in the treatment of angina.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Oral nitroglycerine, a long-acting nitrate preparation, is the most appropriate choice for the prophylactic treatment of chronic stable angina to prevent angina episodes during exertion.

questions.text: A woman who underwent dilatation and curettage for molar pregnancy 6 months ago presents with persistent symptoms of abdominal pain and distention. On further evaluation, the beta- hCG levels were persistently elevated and cannonball foci were found on the chest X-ray. What is the appropriate management in this case? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Methotrexate with folinic acid

 

Explanation:

 

Methotrexate with folinic acid: This is a clear case of post-molar choriocarcinoma with lung metastases. Treatment is based on prognostication and staging. According to the given scoring system, the parameters such as the time interval since the antecedent pregnancy, beta-hCG levels, and the presence of lung metastases suggest a low-risk choriocarcinoma. For low-risk choriocarcinoma, the recommended treatment is multi-dose single-agent chemotherapy with methotrexate. Methotrexate is administered in a multi-dose regimen (Day 1, 3, 5, 7) alternating with folinic acid (Day 2, 4, 6, 8).

 

 

  • < 6: LOW RISK
  • > 7 HIGH RISK

 

Other options:

 

Option B. Methotrexate: Methotrexate alone might be considered for very low-risk cases. However, in this case, with persistent elevated beta-hCG levels and lung metastases, a multi-dose regimen along with folinic acid is preferred to enhance efficacy and reduce toxicity.

 

Option C. EMACO regimen: The EMACO regimen, which includes etoposide, methotrexate, actinomycin D, cyclophosphamide, and vincristine, is used for high-risk choriocarcinoma. This patient's score indicates a low-risk profile, making EMACO unnecessary and more toxic than needed.

 

Option D. Hysterectomy: Hysterectomy is not the first line of treatment for choriocarcinoma, especially in the context of low-risk metastatic disease. It may be considered in cases of heavy bleeding or when the disease is confined to the uterus and chemotherapy is not effective.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Low-risk choriocarcinoma post-molar pregnancy with lung metastases is treated with a multi-dose regimen of methotrexate alternating with folinic acid

 

Ref: Page 789, Williams Gynecology, 3rd edition

questions.text: A child presented with bilateral proptosis. From the peripheral smear, he was suspected to have chloroma. What is the next investigation of choice? (AIIMS NOV 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Bone marrow examination

 

The next investigation of choice, in a child suspected to have a chloroma, is a bone marrow biopsy.

 

Chloroma or granulocytic sarcoma is an extramedullary manifestation that occurs in 2% to 14% of patients with acute myeloid leukemia (AML). It is a localised tumour forming mass occurring in the skin or orbit due to local infiltration of the tissues by leukemic cells. The tumour is greenish in appearance due to the presence of myeloperoxidase.

 

Frequent sites of involvement are the skin, lymph nodes, gastrointestinal tract, bone, soft tissue, testis, and peritoneum. Isolated orbital involvement of myeloid sarcoma is rare. Proptosis is the most common presentation. Other symptoms include lacrimal swelling, conjunctival mass lesion, retinal hemorrhages, ptosis, dystopia. Decreased visual acuity and ocular movement restriction have also been reported.

 

The diagnosis of AML is made by a combination of routine blood picture and bone marrow examination, coupled with cytochemical stains and other special laboratory investigations.

 

The diagnosis of AML is based on the presence of at least 20% myeloid blasts in the bone marrow.

 

Although myeloid sarcomas are radiosensitive, they are managed with systemic chemotherapy in most cases, even in the absence of bone marrow involvement. Surgery and/or radiation therapy may be indicated for symptomatic lesions or tumors causing local organ dysfunction or obstruction.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Platelet count: While important in assessing overall hematologic status, platelet count alone is not sufficient to diagnose chloroma or AML.

 

Option B. WBC count: Similarly, WBC count is part of the complete blood count but does not provide the definitive diagnosis needed in this case.

 

Option C. Flow cytometry: This test can help classify leukemia subtypes by analyzing cell surface markers but is typically performed after a bone marrow examination to confirm the diagnosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For suspected chloroma in the context of AML, a bone marrow examination is the critical next step to confirm the diagnosis and guide treatment.

 

Ref: Robbins pathologic basis of disease 8th edition pg 1150-1154

choices.text: Angioembolization is the treatment of choice
Echinococcus species is involved in Etiology

questions.text: A patient presented with fever and abdominal pain. Investigations showed the given findings. Which of the following statements is true regarding this condition?(NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Echinococcus species is involved in Etiology

 

  • The given CT image shows a cyst in the liver is suggestive of hydatid disease with floating membrane sign.
  • Hydatid disease is caused by Echinococcus granulosus, commonly called the dog tapeworm.
  • MC site of hydatid cyst in human: liver (MC) followed by pulmonary hydatids (2nd MC)

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Surgery is mandatory: Surgical treatment of hydatid cyst indicated when PAIR is contraindicated.

 

Option B. Fine-needle aspiration cytology is diagnostic: FNAC is contra-indicated as rupture of cyst may lead to spillage or anaphylaxis.

 

Option C. Angioembolization is the treatment of choice:  Angioembolization has no role in the management of hydatid cyst.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Hydatid disease of the liver, caused by Echinococcus granulosus, is characterized by the formation of cysts that can be identified using imaging techniques like USG and CECT.
  •  The primary treatment approach includes medical management with albendazole followed by the PAIR procedure or surgery if PAIR is not feasible.
  •  FNAC is contraindicated due to the risk of cyst rupture and anaphylaxis.

questions.text: Which of the following drugs used in the management of diabetes is associated with unexplained diarrhea? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Metformin

 

Metformin is a biguanide used as a first-line treatment for type 2 diabetes mellitus. One of the most common and significant side effects of metformin is gastrointestinal disturbances, particularly diarrhea. This side effect is due to the drug’s effect on the gastrointestinal tract, which can cause alterations in bowel habits, including watery diarrhea.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pioglitazone: This drug is a thiazolidinedione and is not typically associated with diarrhea. Its side effects include fluid retention, weight gain, and an increased risk of bladder cancer.

 

Option B. Sitagliptin: Sitagliptin is a dipeptidyl peptidase-4 (DPP-4) inhibitor. While it can cause gastrointestinal side effects, it is more commonly associated with symptoms like indigestion, nausea, and bloating rather than diarrhea.

 

Option C. Glimepiride: Glimepiride is a sulfonylurea and is generally not associated with diarrhea. Its side effects typically include hypoglycemia and weight gain.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Metformin is commonly associated with unexplained diarrhea as a side effect, making it important for healthcare providers to monitor patients for this gastrointestinal disturbance when prescribing the medication.

questions.text: Selenocysteine is present in which of the following enzymes?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Glutathione peroxidase

 

Option B. Glutathione peroxidase: Glutathione peroxidase is an enzyme that contains selenocysteine in its active site. It plays a vital role in protecting cells from oxidative damage by catalyzing the reduction of hydrogen peroxide and lipid hydroperoxides using glutathione as a cofactor.

 

Other Options

 

Option A. Glutathione reductase: Glutathione reductase is an enzyme involved in the reduction of oxidized glutathione (GSSG) back to its reduced form (GSH). It does not contain selenocysteine.

 

Option C. Thioredoxin peroxidase: Thioredoxin peroxidase (also known as peroxiredoxins) is a group of thiol-containing proteins involved in breaking down hydrogen peroxide during oxidative stress. It does not contain selenocysteine.

 

Option D. Thioredoxin oxidase: Thioredoxin oxidase is not a known enzyme. There is an enzyme called thioredoxin reductase, which is involved in maintaining the redox state of thioredoxin, but it does not contain selenocysteine.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Enzymes which require amino acid selenocysteine at their catalytic site are:
  1. Glutathione Peroxidase
  2. Thioredoxin Reductase
  3. Iodothyronine deiodinase
  • Codon for selenocysteine: UGA
  • This AA is formed by co–translational (during translation) modification (not by post-translational modification).

questions.text: Name the drug that acts on both the marked points: (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Omapatrilat

 

Omapatrilat is a inhibits both neprilysin and Angiotensin-converting enzyme (ACE). As a result, there is a decrease in Angiotensin II and increase in natriuretic peptide levels, promoting natriuresis, diuresis, vasodilation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Sacubitril: Sacubitril inhibits neprilysin reducing breakdown of vasoactive peptides such as natriuretic peptides and bradykinin, therefore increasing their levels leading to vasodilation, diuresis, and counteracting the effects of RAAS. Sacubitril is combined with an ARB, valsartan is indicated for the treatment of heart failure with reduced ejection fraction (HFrEF).

 

Option C. Losartan: Losartan is classified under angiotensin receptor blocker, used in the treatment of hypertension. A/E are Hyperkalemia, Dysgeusia, Postural hypotension. C/I in pregnancy, B/L Renal Artery Stenosis. Losartan decreases serum uric acid levels.

 

Option D. Nesiritide: Nesiritide is a synthetic brain natriuretic peptide (BNP), acts as a natriuretic and vasodilator. Primarily used in acute decompensated heart failure.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Omapatrilat inhibits both neprilysin and angiotensin-converting enzyme, thereby decreasing angiotensin II and increasing natriuretic peptides, promoting natriuresis, diuresis, and vasodilation.

questions.text: Which of the following is not seen in MEN 2B syndrome? (Neet pg 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Parathyroid adenoma

 

Parathyroid adenomas are not seen in MEN 2B. Parathyroid adenomas are typically associated with MEN 1 and MEN 2A syndromes, where hyperparathyroidism is a common feature due to the involvement of the parathyroid glands.

 

Multiple Endocrine Neoplasia type 2B (MEN 2B) is a genetic syndrome characterized by specific clinical features. It is also known as the "Triple M syndrome" because it typically presents with the following:

 

  • Mucosal Neuromas: These are benign growths on the mucous membranes and are a hallmark of MEN 2B.
  • Marfanoid Habitus: This refers to a body habitus resembling Marfan syndrome, with features like long limbs, a tall, slender build, and hyperflexible joints.
  • Medullary Thyroid Carcinoma (MTC): This is a type of thyroid cancer commonly associated with MEN 2B.

 

Other features that can be seen in MEN 2B include pheochromocytomas (tumors of the adrenal glands) and ganglioneuromas (tumors of the nerve cells).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Megacolon: Megacolon can be associated with MEN 2B due to the presence of ganglioneuromatosis affecting the gastrointestinal tract.

 

Option C. Mucosal Neuroma: As mentioned, mucosal neuromas are a classic feature of MEN 2B and one of the reasons it is called "triple M syndrome."

 

Option D. Marfanoid Habitus: This characteristic physical appearance is commonly seen in MEN 2B patients.

 

Educational Objective:

 

MEN 2B syndrome, also known as "triple M syndrome," is characterized by mucosal neuromas, marfanoid habitus, and medullary thyroid carcinoma, but does not involve parathyroid adenomas.

questions.text: A 35-year-old male patient presented to OPD with fever and neurological complications. He was having respiratory difficulty during the examination. Identify the disease transmitted through the life cycle shown in the image. [NEET PG 2024]
questions.solution:
Ans. (d) Nipah virus disease


The life cycle shown in the image involves Pteropus bats, also known as fruit bats or flying foxes, which are natural reservoirs for the Nipah virus. The transmission cycle depicted shows bats contaminating fruits or other food sources with their secretions, which can then be consumed by humans or other animals like pigs, leading to the spread of the virus. Nipah virus is known for causing severe respiratory illness and neurological symptoms, with a high fatality rate of around 50%. There is no vaccine for Nipah virus, and treatment is primarily supportive and symptomatic.

 

Incubation period – 4-14 days

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Zika virus disease: Zika virus is primarily transmitted through mosquito bites and does not involve bats or fruit contamination in its transmission cycle. It primarily causes mild symptoms and is not associated with the severe respiratory and neurological symptoms described here.

 

Option B. Dengue disease: Dengue is transmitted by Aedes mosquitoes and does not involve bats or fruit contamination. It typically presents with fever, headache, and joint pain rather than severe neurological symptoms or respiratory difficulty.

 

Option C. Yellow fever disease: Yellow fever is also transmitted through mosquito bites, mainly the Aedes and Haemagogus species, and does not involve bats. It causes fever, jaundice, and bleeding but does not match the transmission cycle or clinical presentation described.

 

Educational Objective:


Nipah virus is transmitted through contact with Pteropus bats, contaminated food, or animals that have been exposed to the virus. It causes severe respiratory and neurological symptoms with a high fatality rate and no available vaccine.

choices.text: A, B & C
A, B, C & D

questions.text:
Which of the following is correct about the drugs used in Gout? (INICET Nov 2020)

A. Aspirin is not used as it decreases the uric acid excretion

B. Diclofenac is used as it concentrates in the joint

C. Indomethacin is used as it acts by multiple pathways

D. Aspirin is used as it is most powerful NSAID
questions.solution:
Ans. A. A, B & C

 

Options A. Aspirin is not used as it decreases the uric acid excretion: This statement remains correct. Aspirin at low doses can decrease uric acid excretion, potentially worsening gout. Therefore, it is generally not recommended in the management of gout.

 

Options B. Diclofenac is used as it concentrates in the joint: Diclofenac is commonly used in the management of gout due to its anti-inflammatory properties. It gets concentrated in joints and its effect in reducing inflammation and pain in gout is beneficial.

 

Options C. Indomethacin is used as it acts by multiple pathways: Indomethacin is indeed used in the treatment of gout. It is an NSAID that works by inhibiting the production of prostaglandins. It has multiple pathways of action including inhibition of COX and decrease in rate of phagocytosis of urate crystals.

 

Other Options:

 

Options D. Aspirin is used as it is the most powerful NSAID: This statement is incorrect for reasons previously mentioned. Aspirin, particularly at low doses, is not recommended for gout due to its potential to increase serum uric acid levels.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The preferred treatment for an acute gout attack is an NSAID (nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drug), such as indomethacin.
  • A typical first-line treatment for gout is indomethacin. Besides suppressing prostaglandin synthesis, indomethacin and other NSAIDs also reduce rate of crystal phagocytosis.
  • Furthermore, intraarticular steroids like methylprednisolone or triamcinolone may be given.
  • Aspirin is not utilized because it promotes renal retention of uric acid.

questions.text:
A 70-year-old male patient was undergoing laparoscopic cholecystectomy. Halfway through the surgery, a sudden drop in EtCO2 to 8 mm Hg was noted. His SpO2 became 90% and blood pressure dropped to 70/50 mmHg and peak airway pressure was 18 cm of H2O. What is the diagnosis?

 

  1. CO2 embolism
  2. Severe bronchospasm
  3. Pneumothorax
  4. Single bronchus intubation

 

EtCO2-End-tidal carbon dioxide
questions.solution:
Ans. C. 1 only

 

Explanation:

 

1. CO2 embolism: During laparoscopic procedures, CO2 is used to insufflate the abdomen, creating a pneumoperitoneum. This allows for better visualization and manipulation of the internal structures. If there's a vascular injury, especially to a large vein, CO2 can enter the circulation and cause an embolism. This can lead to sudden cardiovascular collapse and a sharp drop in EtCO2, as observed in the scenario. Also, a sudden drop in oxygen saturation (SpO2) can occur due to the embolism obstructing the pulmonary vasculature. The significant drop in EtCO2, in this case, is indicative of a CO2 embolism.

 

Other Options:

 

2. Severe bronchospasm: Bronchospasm would lead to an increase in peak airway pressure, which wasn't seen in this scenario (the peak airway pressure was 18 cm of H2O, which is within the normal range). Moreover, EtCO2 would generally be elevated in bronchospasm due to retention of CO2, not decreased as seen in the scenario.

 

3. Pneumothorax: A pneumothorax could cause a drop in SpO2 and blood pressure. However, the EtCO2 drop to 8 mm Hg in the setting of laparoscopic surgery more specifically suggests a CO2 embolism. Additionally, one would expect an increase in peak airway pressures with a tension pneumothorax.

 

4. Single bronchus intubation: If the endotracheal tube is advanced too far and intubates a single bronchus, it would lead to ventilation of one lung only. This can cause a decrease in SpO2, but the sudden drop in EtCO2 as seen in the scenario isn't typical for single bronchus intubation.

 

Educational Objective :

 

A sudden and significant drop in EtCO2 during laparoscopic surgery, along with a decrease in SpO2 and blood pressure, strongly suggests a CO2 embolism.

 

Ref: Miller’s Anesthesia, 9th Ed. Pg 1879

questions.text: Broca's area is located in which part of the cerebral cortex? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Inferior frontal gyrus

 

Broca's area is primarily located in the posterior part of the frontal lobe, specifically within the left hemisphere. It is divided into two regions: Brodmann area 44 (Broca's area proper) and Brodmann area 45 (Pars triangularis). This region is crucial for language production, including the ability to form grammatically correct sentences and articulate speech.

 

 

Broca's area is situated in the inferior frontal gyrus of the dominant cerebral hemisphere, which is typically the left hemisphere in right-handed individuals and a significant portion of left-handed individuals.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Superior Temporal Gyrus: While the superior temporal gyrus is involved in language processing, it is not the primary site for speech production or Broca's area. Instead, the superior temporal gyrus is associated with auditory processing and speech comprehension.

 

Areas present in superior temporal gyrus: 

 

Brodmann Area 41 (Primary Auditory Cortex) is primarily responsible for the initial processing of auditory information. It receives and processes auditory signals from the ears and is involved in basic sound perception.

 

Brodmann Area 42 (Auditory Association Cortex) is involved in higher-level auditory processing. It helps in recognizing complex auditory stimuli, such as speech, music, and environmental sounds

 

Option C. Angular Gyrus: The angular gyrus, located in the parietal lobe, is involved in various functions, including reading, writing, and language comprehension. It plays a role in translating visual information into language.

 

Areas present in angular gyrus is Brodmann Area 39. It is associated with processes like reading, writing, and language comprehension. It also plays a role in the integration of visual, auditory, and somatosensory information, contributing to our ability to understand and interpret the world around us.

 

Option D. Postcentral Gyrus: The postcentral gyrus is located in the parietal lobe and is primarily associated with sensory functions, particularly somatosensory processing. It is not directly involved in speech production or language processing. Brodmann Area 3, 1, and 2 (Primary Somatosensory Cortex): These areas together make up the primary somatosensory cortex, which is located in the postcentral gyrus. It is responsible for our ability to perceive sensations such as touch, pressure, temperature, and proprioception (awareness of body position).

 

Educational Objective:

 

Broca's area is situated in the inferior frontal gyrus.

 

  • Broca's motor speech area - (44,45) is located in the inferior frontal gyrus.
  • Wernicke's area - (22) is located in the superior temporal gyrus.

questions.text: A husband and wife presented to the outpatient department with complaints of the husband's premature ejaculation, which is leading to frequent conflicts between them. Which of the following non-pharmacological techniques is most appropriate for treatment? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Squeeze Technique

 

For the management of premature ejaculation, the Squeeze Technique is a specific non-pharmacological method that is often recommended. This technique involves sexual stimulation until the individual is close to ejaculation. At that point, the partner squeezes the shaft of the penis (coronal ridge of glans) for several seconds, which can delay ejaculation. This process is repeated several times before ejaculation is allowed to occur. The Squeeze Technique helps in increasing the time before ejaculation and is directly targeted at managing premature ejaculation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Sensate Focus Technique: While this technique, which involves non-genital pleasuring, can be helpful in reducing performance anxiety and improving sexual communication, it is not specifically designed for the treatment of premature ejaculation. It is useful for erectile dysfunction.

 

Option C. Exposure and Response Prevention: This is a technique used primarily in the treatment of obsessive-compulsive disorder and is not typically employed for premature ejaculation.

 

Option D. Cognitive Behavioral Therapy (CBT): CBT can be useful for addressing underlying psychological issues contributing to sexual dysfunction, but it is a more general approach and not as specifically targeted for premature ejaculation as the Squeeze Technique.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Squeeze Technique is a specific non-pharmacological method effective in the management of premature ejaculation. It involves squeezing the penis before the point of ejaculation to delay it and can be repeated several times to increase the time before ejaculation.

 

Reference: Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 12th edition, Page 531.

questions.text: A 25-year-old male presented to the clinic with a complaint of the feeling of insects crawling under the skin. Which of the following drug abuse can cause the symptoms of this patient?( NEET PG 2020 )
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Cocaine

 

The sensation of insects or bugs crawling on or under the skin, known as "formication", is classically associated with cocaine use. While it can also be seen with the use of other stimulants, including amphetamines, it is most emblematic of cocaine intoxication.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Cannabis: Typically results in effects like altered perception, increased appetite, and paranoia.

 

Option C. Amphetamine: Another stimulant that can lead to increased energy, euphoria, and sometimes similar tactile hallucinations.

 

Option D. Alcohol: Produces symptoms such as impaired judgment, slurred speech, and incoordination.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Cocaine intoxication can lead to tactile hallucinations, notably the sensation known as formication. This sensation, often described as feeling like bugs crawling on or under the skin, is a classic symptom of cocaine use and can lead to skin picking and resultant lesions. This is also known as cocaine bugs or magnun phenomenon.

 

Reference: Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 11th edition, Page No 676.
